top_categories.workout_context: At mile 60 of 124, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
The Gralloch's Scottish Highlands gravel (75%), Singletrack/dirt (25%) forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 124 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic The Gralloch's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before September.
93ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At The Gralloch, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 124 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Gralloch. Train it until it feels boring.
124 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At The Gralloch, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
11,483ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
11,483ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on scottish Highlands—remote technical terrain. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.

race_overlay.heat: September in Scottish Highlands, Scotland — September: 8-18°C, 40% rain chance, autumn conditions, hypothermia risk. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before The Gralloch — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Gralloch’s 124 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at The Gralloch demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride scottish highlands—remote technical terrain at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: scottish highlands gravel (75%), singletrack/dirt (25%), remote terrain. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 124 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 124 miles of scottish highlands—remote technical terrain in Scottish Highlands, Scotland.
